Posts.Content: Maybe I wasn't clear. What I meant is that if I try to precertify the procedure via my insurance company (A) at radiology group X, and A refuses, I can't then tell X "OK I want the procedure but at the self-pay rate". If I want to get it done at X, I'd have to pay the much higher rate. I'm guessing that if A refuses it for X and I then go to radiology group Y and say I want the self-pay rate, that would be fine since no precertification attempt was made for Y. But X and Y may or may not not have the same equipment (e.g. 3T), and also the precertification process would take time and would probably be fruitless (although in Gerard's case it worked fine - thanks for that reply!) . Not sure if I cleared it up; please reply if not, or if it still sounds fishy.
Posts.Title: mpMRI cost MAY be (much) lower than meets the eye - if a patient self-pays

Posts.Content: Djin, my impression is it's a state regulation or possibly something in the contract between the insurance company and the radiology group, but I could be wrong.
Posts.Title: mpMRI cost MAY be (much) lower than meets the eye - if a patient self-pays

Posts.Content: Doing some research the other day, I called a radiology group (not one that offers mpMRI) and was very surprised to learn that self-pay patients pay less - sometimes far less - for MRIs than patients who go through insurance. I then called the radiology group where I would likely have my mpMRI (if, of course, my urologist orders one) and they quoted me a self-pay mpMRI price under $650 vs a with-insurance price of over $1,650. Also, both radiology groups said that if one tries to precertify an MRI at their facility using insurance and the insurance company refuses to precertify that MRI, one is stuck paying the higher price and can't then switch to self-pay for that procedure. (Note: This could possibly be a state-by-state situation.) Given the apparent policy of insurers to not cover mpMRI before biopsy (that does seem accurate for my insurance company), it may make sense for patients to consider paying out of pocket if they want an mpMRI before biopsy and can afford that cost. The person I spoke to at the second radiology group seemed well-versed in these matters, but it's certainly possible I got the figures or other details wrong. If anyone else feels like calling in their area to do a sanity check of this, that might be a good idea.

Posts.Title: mpMRI cost MAY be (much) lower than meets the eye - if a patient self-pays

Posts.Content: Due to a fairly high PSA reading (6.4 with 17.2% free at age 63, up from the mid-3s 18 months ago, as I mentioned in a previous thread), I made an appointment with a urologist. I figured I'd be able to present a more thorough picture to the urologist if I had a reading from the ExoDx Intelliscore urine test, so during the 2-week wait for the urologist appointment I asked my PCP if he would order it and he agreed (half-heartedly, saying he wouldn't know enough to expertly interpret the results). The results showed a score of 13.11%, which, encouragingly, is below the 15.6% cutoff point (see later in post for the fine print). I showed the ExoDx literature to the urologist and told him my score (which I got verbally from my PCP's office but hadn't yet gotten a copy of the report). The urologist was not familiar with the test but seemed interested and said he would research it. I asked whether a PHI or 4Kscore test might be a good next step, and he said that I should wait 2 or 3 more weeks (i.e. 5 or 6 weeks from the initial PSA reading, to allow any temporary prostate problems that might have contributed to the initial PSA to resolve themselves) and then get a 4Kscore test and we'd work from there. (He accurately said, "I see you want to avoid a biopsy". I'm not sure this was his preferred course of action, but he seemed OK with it for now. If anything further is needed after 4Kscore, mpMRI might be next.) I realize that an ExoDx reading below the cutoff doesn't necessarily mean that I don't have a Gleason 7 (or above) tumor, but in my mind it makes it more likely that the urologist and I can actively take some weeks to explore the best next step. When I first spoke to Exosome Diagnostics (which makes and processes the ExoDx test), I asked whether an ordering physician could be labeled as a non-urologist in their database so that Exosome wouldn't give his/her name to other patients, and they got back to me and said yes. As far as the cost of the test, while the self-pay price is $800, if a patient has health insurance the maximum out-of-pocket cost that Exosome charges is $300. In response to a follow-up question, they said You had also voiced concerns over a potentially high deductible from your insurance company. Even if the test is not fully covered, the max out of pocket cost to you would be $300. But of course these things change, so if interested you'd probably want to ask them directly. Fine print re ExoDx test (from the report, paraphrased by me): It's for age 50+ with PSA 2-10 being considered for an initial prostate biopsy. A score below the 15.6% cutoff has a Negative Predictive Value (NPV) of 91% for Gleason 7+. Score should be used in conjunction with other standard-of-care prognostic info (so for example I assume a PSA of 9 with an ExoDx of 17 would carry a higher risk than a PSA of 5 with an ExoDx of 17). One question I have for other Forum Brothers: The 4Kscore test report provides total PSA and free PSA info (as well as the total 4Kscore), but since it's done by Bioreference Labs, the PSA methodology wouldn't necessarily be comparable to that of Labcorp where I got my other PSA tests. Has anyone had experience with how Labcorp and Bioreference PSA values from similar timeframes have compared?
Posts.Signature: DOB 1955 PSA: 7/2014 to 10/2015: various readings ranged from 2.6 to 3.6 12/2015 3.1 1/2017 3.4 (free 18.5%) or 3.9 (these are 2 different readings from same blood sample for 2 different doctors) 7/13/2018 6.4 (free 17.2%) or 6.6 (these are 2 different readings from same blood sample for 2 different doctors) 8/30/2018 3.73 (free 18%, 4Kscore 12) ExoDx Intelliscore 8/2018 13.11% DRE: negative 8/2018

Posts.Title: ExoDx (Ordered by PCP) Encouraging Score, and Urologist Initial Visit

Posts.Content: Markiz, I'm waiting for the results of the ExoDx Intelliscore myself. I hope things turn out in the best possible manner for you. You may want to read the JAMA Oncology article that describes what the test shows and doesn't show. The link is https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...rticle/2506709 Someone with a reading above the 15.6% cutoff point does not necessarily have a high risk of high-grade prostate cancer. Rather, the article states that "A binary cut point with a negative predictive value (NPV) of greater than 95% was selected." As I understand it (and that 4-word qualifier also applies to everything that follows here, since I'm far from an expert), that means that if one's test value is BELOW 15.6%, there's a 95% chance that a biopsy would NOT show high grade cancer. (That's JUST based on the Intelliscore and doesn't incorporate factors such as PSA, family history, etc.) Being above the cutoff does not mean that one would or wouldn't have a high-grade biopsy. In that article, if you click on Figure 3, you can see that at approximately your test result (26 or so on the vertical scale), there are plenty of blue bars ("Biopsy negative/GS6") but also a fair number of yellow (GS3+4) and red (GS4+3 and higher) bars. I think DjinTonic's statement that "As to monitoring, what would you be waiting for? -- Your PSA to go even higher? A nodule to be felt on your DRE? That could be flirting with danger." is spot on. As far a whether to pursue a 3T mpMRI before a biopsy, I'm probably on that path (I'm a newbie so take my opinion for what it's worth). As DjinTonic said, for someone who has not had a biopsy, the cost of an mpMRI may very well be out of pocket, and each guy needs to make his own judgments as to what the best path for him is. Also, it might well take time to find a urologist who is willing to work with mpMRI requests, get an appointment with him, wait for the mpMRI, then wait to get the biopsy done. On the flip side, what I've read says that 3T mpMRI TRUS fusion biopsy is better than a standard TRUS biopsy. Feel free to PM me if you want to know how I'm going about all of it or any other details.
Posts.Title: Above cut off point IntelliScore on ExoDx Report

Posts.Content: "Whether or not your URO MD is an investor in the company is different issue. You are free to ask him/her." Interestingly, Exosome Diagnostics (the maker of ExoDx) was acquired this week by a $6 billion (market value) company named Bio-Techne for $250 million plus up to $325 million in contingent consideration based on achievement of future milestones. To me that is somewhat of a validation of the technology, since I'm sure Bio-Techne did lots of due dilligence before making the purchase. (Someone who had invested in Exosome could still benefit from its future success by virtue of the contingent consideration, so theoretically conflicts of interest could occur. Likewise someone who owns stock in Bio-Techne could theoretically benefit to some degree.) By the way, FDA approval was not required for ExoDx. "This test was evaluated and its performance characteristics determined by Exosome Diagnostics Inc. It has not been cleared or approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The FDA has determined that such clearance or approval is not necessary. Exosome Diagnostics is certified under the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) act of 1988 as qualified to perform high complexity clinical testing".

Posts.Title: Above cut off point IntelliScore on ExoDx Report

Posts.Content: To throw another possibility into the mix: google: "video from recent cyberknife" Dr. Blacksburg talks about many positives of of cyberknife for prostate cancer. There are also (plenty of?) professionals who feel that it is not the best choice. There have been studies, but probably less long term than for other radiation treatments. I've also read that boosts can increase the effectiveness of radiation treatments. One of many articles can be found by googling: Outcomes of hypofractionated stereotactic body radiotherapy boost for intermediate and high-risk prostate cancer

Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: (This is only from what I have read - fortunately not from personal experience since my risk level seems lower.) One option may be SBRT, of which Cyberknife is probably the most common vehicle. It seems that there are professionals who feel that it has similar, or almost similar, benefits as standard radiation treatment with fewer side effects. I'm sure there are other professionals who feel otherwise. There have been studies carried out -- search on SBRT for intermediate risk prostate cancer. Good luck, and as others have stated, research the heck out of your options. Don't hesitate to call Cyberknife centers and ask questions; the worse they can say is that they can't help you over the phone. There are also videos.

Posts.Title: New to Prostate Cancer I'm confused and angry

Posts.Content: My impression is that this is common (not sure about hospitals). For example the Princeton Radiology website says "Princeton Radiology has acquired UroNav software by Invivo. With this new software we are able to gather pre-biopsy MRI images of the prostate and then seamlessly transfer them to local Urologists. Using UroNav, these Urologists can fuse the pre-biopsy MRI images with real time ultrasound-guided biopsy images for excellent delineation of the prostate and suspicious lesions, as well as clear visualization of the biopsy needle – allowing Urologists to directly aim biopsy needed at lesions. Better images means better results." (Note: I believe the radiology group actually uses Invivo's Dynacad and the urologist uses Uronav.)

Posts.Title: MRI Fusion biopsy, mix & match ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Markiz My ExoDx Intelliscore test came back with score of 26. Urine sample was collected after the DRE which released some PCA3 into the urethra. Could that mess up with the test results? I can't find the instructions that were in the kit, but I'm pretty sure it specifically said that if DRE is to be done, it should be after the urine collection. QUESTION: Markiz, how long after the DRE was your urine sample collected? (If it was within a few hours or less, that tells me the doctor wasn't aware of the specification or didn't inform you of it.) As to whether the DRE could affect the test, that's a great question. Possibly Exosome Diagnostics customer service could be of help. Also, I'll try to send you a PM if I get a chance.

Posts.Title: Encouraging PSA Retest (consistent with ExoDx score)

Posts.Content: I had a PSA scare 2 months ago, with a reading in the mid-6's, up from the high 3's a year and a half earlier. I just got the results of my PSA retest, and the reading is 3.73. I should get the 4Kscore result in a couple of days, but I'd be surprised if it's anything worrisome. I made sure before this PSA retest not to ejaculate for several days. Specifically I waited (and waited) 5 days before getting the blood test. Two months ago I had only waited about 36 hours (and had previously ejaculated a few times that week), after having read one study that seemed to indicate that things return to normal for most men by 24 to 48 hours. But I guess I'm not like most men, or there was some other factor at work. (I interpreted another study as indicating that the older one is, the longer it might take for the PSA to return to normal after ejaculation, partly due to BPH prevalence -- but my understanding of all this is quite murky.) To play it safe, I also avoided getting the retest when I was experiencing any significant discomfort that could potentially be (even non-bacterial) prostatitis. In the interim I had taken an ExoDx Intelliscore urine test (ordered by my PCP, as I detailed in another thread) that showed a score of 13.11, which is on the good side of the 95% Negative Predictive Value range for clinically significant (Gleason 7+) prostate cancer. (Note: The ExoDx test is described as a "non-invasive test that does not require a digital rectal exam", but I didn't realize until reading the test instructions that IF a DRE is being done, it should be done AFTER the urine collection. This is VERY UNLIKE another urine test, SelectMDx, which REQUIRES a POST-DRE sample. All of this is new territory for most urologists, so if a patient is planning on requesting or taking an ExoDx Intelliscore test, he should be proactive in ensuring that a DRE, if there is one, be done AFTER taking the urine sample.) To me the availability of the ExoDx test as an additional data point was a huge positive. The encouraging result provided me with an extra few weeks of relative optimism while waiting for the PSA retest, and now provides, in my mind, additional support for holding off on a biopsy unless the 4Kscore result is problematical. (If the ExoDx result had been less encouraging, it would have provided additional support FOR a (MRI-guided?) biopsy.) Interestingly, my urologist, who had not previously been familiar with the ExoDx test, correctly predicted based on the ExoDx result that the PSA retest result would be encouraging. The forum brothers who have been diagnosed with clinically significant PCa (or other risky PCa) understandably suggest erring on the side of biopsy (despite the fact that there are some risks with biopsy) when PSA shows a potential problem. Over time, based on prospective accumulated ExoDx experience of other forum brothers, perhaps a bit of an opinion shift will occur in cases with encouraging ExoDx results and SLIGHTLY problematical PSA. Maybe in those cases, a 3T mpMRI could be an (admittedly imperfect) tie-breaker if the patient strongly wishes to attempt to avoid a biopsy.
Posts.Signature: DOB 1955 PSA: 7/2014 to 10/2015: various readings ranged from 2.6 to 3.6 12/2015 3.1 1/2017 3.4 (free 18.5%) or 3.9 (these are 2 different readings from same blood sample for 2 different doctors) 7/13/2018 6.4 (free 17.2%) or 6.6 (these are 2 different readings from same blood sample for 2 different doctors) 8/30/2018 3.73 (free 18%, 4Kscore 12) ExoDx Intelliscore 8/2018 13.11% DRE: negative 8/2018
Posts.Title: Encouraging PSA Retest (consistent with ExoDx score)

Posts.Content: I'm 63 years old and recently got a PSA reading of 6.4 (17.2% free) with a negative DRE as per my very experienced Primary Care Physician. Values 17 months earlier were 3.4 and 18.5%, and all prior results were 3.6 or lower. I don't know the PSA density. I'm REALLY hoping to avoid a biopsy if possible. Whichever urologist I go to, I'm planning to ask for the ExoDx Intelliscore urine test and a multiparametric MRI, and if both of those show low risk, I would lobby to avoid a biopsy. (This has very recently become more accepted, even with just the MRI portion and not the urine test, as per http://www.bjuinternational.com/bjui...ostate-cancer/ ; also, the subsequent biopsy, if needed, on average uses many fewer needles.) The urologist I'm planning to go to (next week) is one who is reviewed by patients as being very knowledgeable and caring, owns the practice, and schedules a 30-minute initial appointment. But I have no reason to think he has experience with MRI-guided biopsy. If an MRI and/or the urine test indicate that a biopsy is really necessary, would it be simple and effective for a urologist who has not done an MRI-guided biopsy before to do it? (There is a radiology group in my area that recently started doing multiparametric MRI, will use a 3T machine if done at a particular location, and will send the results and raw data(?) to urologists.) Or I'm guessing I could take the MRI results to a urologist who is experienced in MRI-guided biopsy. I did find a urologist in my area whose bio says he's done MRI-guided biopsy, but I'm hesitant to make my initial appointment with him because he's part of a big practice (probably less flexibility to say "sure, let's see if the tests say you can avoid a biopsy") that only allocates 10 minutes even for an initial appointment. Any guidance in choosing a urologist in this case, or on any other aspects of my situation, would be appreciated.
Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: I'm 63 years old and recently got a PSA reading of 6.4 (17.2% free) with a negative DRE as per my very experienced Primary Care Physician. Values 17 months earlier were 3.4 and 18.5%, and all prior results were 3.6 or lower. I don't know the PSA density. I'm REALLY hoping to avoid a biopsy if possible. Whichever urologist I go to, I'm planning to ask for the ExoDx Intelliscore urine test and a multiparametric MRI, and if both of those show low risk, I would lobby to avoid a biopsy. (This has very recently become more accepted, even with just the MRI portion and not the urine test, as per http://www.bjuinternational.com/bjui...ostate-cancer/ ; also, the subsequent biopsy, if needed, on average uses many fewer needles.) The urologist I'm planning to go to (next week) is one who is reviewed by patients as being very knowledgeable and caring, owns the practice, and schedules a 30-minute initial appointment. But I have no reason to think he has experience with MRI-guided biopsy. If an MRI and/or the urine test indicate that a biopsy is really necessary, would it be simple and effective for a urologist who has not done an MRI-guided biopsy before to do it? (There is a radiology group in my area that recently started doing multiparametric MRI, will use a 3T machine if done at a particular location, and will send the results and raw data(?) to urologists.) Or I'm guessing I could take the MRI results to a urologist who is experienced in MRI-guided biopsy. I did find a urologist in my area whose bio says he's done MRI-guided biopsy, but I'm hesitant to make my initial appointment with him because he's part of a big practice (probably less flexibility to say "sure, let's see if the tests say you can avoid a biopsy") that only allocates 10 minutes even for an initial appointment. Any guidance in choosing a urologist in this case, or on any other aspects of my situation, would be appreciated.
Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: I'm 63 years old and recently got a PSA reading of 6.4 (17.2% free) with a negative DRE as per my very experienced Primary Care Physician. Values 17 months earlier were 3.4 and 18.5%, and all prior results were 3.6 or lower. I don't know the PSA density. I'm REALLY hoping to avoid a biopsy if possible. Whichever urologist I go to, I'm planning to ask for the ExoDx Intelliscore urine test and a multiparametric MRI, and if both of those show low risk, I would lobby to avoid a biopsy. (This has very recently become more accepted, even with just the MRI portion and not the urine test, as per http://www.bjuinternational.com/bjui...ostate-cancer/ ; also, the subsequent biopsy, if needed, on average uses many fewer needles.) The urologist I'm planning to go to (next week) is one who is reviewed by patients as being very knowledgeable and caring, owns the practice, and schedules a 30-minute initial appointment. But I have no reason to think he has experience with MRI-guided biopsy. If an MRI and/or the urine test indicate that a biopsy is really necessary, would it be simple and effective for a urologist who has not done an MRI-guided biopsy before to do it? (There is a radiology group in my area that recently started doing multiparametric MRI, will use a 3T machine if done at a particular location, and will send the results and raw data(?) to urologists.) Or I'm guessing I could take the MRI results to a urologist who is experienced in MRI-guided biopsy. I did find a urologist in my area whose bio says he's done MRI-guided biopsy, but I'm hesitant to make my initial appointment with him because he's part of a big practice (probably less flexibility to say "sure, let's see if the tests say you can avoid a biopsy") that only allocates 10 minutes even for an initial appointment. Any guidance in choosing a urologist in this case, or on any other aspects of my situation, would be appreciated.
